results.title: Remembering Marilyn
results.creator_credit: Andrew Solt, Harry Arends, Susan F Walker, Asta Productions and Scotti-Vinnedge Productions
results.brief_description: Lee Remick hosts this tribute to screen goddess Marilyn Monroe, charting her rise to fame from her early years as struggling brunette photographer’s model to her later incarnation as a successful actress and blonde bombshell. This documentary examines the continuing appeal of Monroe and the private hell hidden behind the radiant public facade, and features rare footage of her teenage years, an early television commercial for Royal Triton Fuel, her appearance on the Jack Benny Show, her visit to Korea to perform for the American troops, her controversial rendition of Happy Birthday for President Kennedy, and clips from some of her most famous film roles. Also includes interviews with Gloria Steinem, Robert Wagner, Robert Mitchum, Susan Strasberg, and Monroe herself.

results.title: Remembering Life
results.brief_description: A history of Life magazine which first appeared in America in November 1936. Life pioneered pictorial journalism and in the process radically altered the course of the print media. Editors, journalists and photographers involved with its production, discuss the incredible power and influence had by this pictorial.

results.title: Remembering country
results.creator_credit: Kate Gillick, Charlotte Seymour, Harold Furber, Australian Film Commission and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: An autobiographical documentary which tells the story of a member of the ‘stolen generation’ of Aboriginal children of mixed descent. In 1957 at age four, Harold Furber was taken from the desert regions near Alice Springs by the Commonwealth Government, and placed in a Methodist missionary camp on Croker Island, 225 km north-east of Darwin. Telling his story through the use of slides and archival footage taken at the mission during the fifties and sixties, Furber recounts a childhood where his fragile but growing feeling of belonging to a new family and home on Croker Island, was continually shattered by the confusion and sense of loss and pain caused by his separation from his family and his country. Carrying a deep sense of alienation and bitterness into his adult life, Furber attempts through this documentary, to reconstruct his fractured identity by reconnecting with his birthplace and community. Narrated by Harold Furber. Written by Kate Gillick and Harold Furber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kate Gillick, Charlotte Seymour, Harold Furber, Australian Film Commission and Film Victoria

results.title: Remembering a champion
results.brief_description:
Made in collaboration with Lockington and Districts Living Heritage Complex, this short, comprising of stills, archival excerpts and narrative commentary, celebrates the memory of Kevin Sarre - a champion in an era when a “gun shearer” was something like a pop star.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Margaret O’Brien and Des Pentreath.
Excerpt from Australian Wool Board promotional film reproduced courtesy of the Arnold and Saare family collection and the Australian Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

results.title: Dad's goanna
results.brief_description:
One of two stories in MAP about the stuffed animal displays in the Murtoa Museum. In this short doco, Meryl Duder talks about her life in Murtoa as a young girl of 10, relating the tale of “dad’s goanna” and how it ended up preserved in Mr Hill’s house in Murtoa in a room full of many other stuffed animals. Years later, on returning to Murtoa with her daughter and to the Murtoa Museum, Meryl was delighted to be able to point out and say “there’s dad’s goanna”.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made with the assistance of Murtoa Historical Society and Murtoa Lions Club.
The James Hill Bird Collection is held by the Lions Club of Murtoa under a special scientific license.

results.title: A New dress (35 years of family sewing)
results.brief_description:
Bev Scott has been making clothes for her family for thirty years. To the sporadic background sound of a sewing machine, family members are interviewed showing their home-made clothes to describe the woman who created them.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Bev Scott, Heather Scott, Robyn Ritchie, Erin Ritchie and Lauren Ritchie. Made in collaboration with Showcase Wangaratta.

group_siblings.title: The School of Stanley J. Ellis

results.title: The School of Stanley J. Ellis
results.brief_description:
A short history of Stanley J. Ellis (b. 1899), influential artisan and teacher in the field of decorative metalwork and enamelling whose intricate work represents some of the finest examples of craftsmanship to be produced in the arts and craft movement of early 20th century Australia. His work is permanently held at the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum in regional Victoria and in this film we see some of those highly acclaimed pieces. The film also features interviews with Peter Perry (Director, Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum) and Beth Sinclair, one of Ellis’s students.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made in association with the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Museum.

results.title: Mourning & memory (a fabric memorial)
results.brief_description:
Short documentary about the Korean War Honour Roll Quilt made by the Coleraine Sit and Sew Group to commemorate the 340 Australian soldiers killed in the Korean War. Includes stills and personal commentary from the Coleraine community and some of those who contributed to the 1000 hours of work it took to complete the quilt.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Nola Gunning, Sherri Robertson, Maurie Butterworth, Lynn Gunning, Melba Plush and Janet Stanton.

results.title: Reproductive technology: facts and issues
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Pearl, Neil Barrett and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: This video is designed for students in years 10-12. Part one looks at recent technological advances in the field of reproduction and Part two raises some of the legal and ethical issues involved in such technology.
